question.text: An inorganic Compound <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>'</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mo>'</mo></math> on treatment with concentrated <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi>SO</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></math> produces brown fumes and gives dark brown ring with <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>FeSO</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></math> in presence of concentrated <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi>SO</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></math>. Also Compound <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>'</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mo>'</mo></math> gives precipitate <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>'</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi><mo>'</mo></math>, when its solution in dilute <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>HCl</mi></math> is treated with <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi></math> gas. The precipitate <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>'</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi><mo>'</mo></math> on treatment with concentrated <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>HNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> followed by excess of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>NH</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mi>OH</mi></math> further gives deep blue coloured solution, Compound <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>'</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mo>'</mo></math> is:

solution.text: ∴X→CuNO32
